review_title: Toxic workplace with incompetent management style

Employee benefits and well-being practices non-existent - company used to host yearly conferences, Christmas parties, holiday gifting, and incentives. These have all been removed without explanation despite the explanation being clear. The company has gone from offering luxury experiences and gifting to nothing. Annual Leave limitations - no allowance during November - January. History of not allowing employees to take or carry on their legally accrued holiday allowance during times of lockdown. Micromanagement and lack of proper communication skills from management teams across the business. Many store managers are simply inexperienced and incredibly passive aggressive towards their client advisors. Majority of employees are also too scared to bring these issues to attention due to justified concerns over retaliation. Favouritism - top sellers receive significantly better treatment by management in matters as simple as attitude expressed towards them. Being on receiving end of either one is incredibly uncomfortable. High turnover of employees - at joining, the brand was filled with loyal and tenured employees, it has since managed those employees out of the business and new hires are only lasting 6 months on average due to poor working conditions and lack of good pay. Every employee I know is or has considered changing workplaces. Unreasonable expectations - such as reprimands for not checking work phone / communications on days off (not only unreasonable but also illegal). Expectations of serving clients back to back for hours without breaks for drink or bathroom. When taken, those small breaks are timed and managers are known to pressure employees into returning to the shop floor. I have witnessed managers following employees to the bathrooms on numerous occasions. Lack of care - personal circumstances are irrelevant and unimportant to the business. I have seen employees reprimanded and placed on disciplinary measures for matters such as long term sicknesses, homelessness, and family issues. HR team which is neither human nor resourceful - reps are incredibly condescending and only speak in formulaic terms without providing any real answers or solutions. The only competent HR Manager left the business. Incompetent Customer Service team - providing very contradictory and incorrect information to clients which then has to be corrected in store. They create more customer complaints than they resolve. Despite enormous amounts of feedback they do not acknowledge fault or improve. Lack of consistency - company policies are not adhered to. Managers authorise complimentary services the moment they lose control over a client issue. This undermines all the work a client advisor puts in to explain policies such as repair charges. Company policies regarding in-store operations are also not adhered. Matters which are strictly to be performed by management are delegated to other members of staff. Hiring outside of the business - the company is incredibly reluctant to promote employees and provide employees with the tools they need to progress. They predominantly hire outsiders for management roles. Unfortunately, these hires are not only unfamiliar with the business but very rude and lacking reasonable management style. Salary increase rates more than halved during the pandemic. Severe inconsistency in salaries across the business also. The company is more than able to create a tiered salary system and yet has not done so.

review_title: Depends on how easily you get stressed
pros:
Thorough training process (mine was 10 weeks), which is a pass/fail course. The nice thing is that those who failed the course were put into a different position in the company rather than being let go.

You can listen to music while you work (on a device with no internet access or video/voice recording), which I think is completely necessary, as your days are spent completely solo, staring into a microscope. 

It's a dependable job, and allows for more holidays/vacation/sick days than many other places I have worked in the past.

The atmosphere is pretty much what you make it. For me it was a bit stressful, just because I tend to be on the perfectionistic side and got down on myself when I had work sent back or rejected by QA (but rejections are completely normal, and they do allow a lot of learning time to correct mistakes). It seemed like a nice atmosphere with the employees, although there are always those who take everything a *bit* too seriously and can cause you some stress, but it really just depends on how much you internalize things.
cons:
Make sure you ask a TON of questions to your trainer/manager/HR rep/attendance coordinator, because the company definitely does not give you all the information you need on a silver platter. My fellow trainees and I had to make multiple trips to HR to figure out how to sign up for the company website, benefits, when we would get our sign-on bonus (which came 5 weeks later than promised on day 1), how their very complicated attendance system worked, etc. It seemed like company information was dispersed among five of our superiors, and we had to spend a lot of time figuring out who had accurate information on the subjects we had questions about. 

The hours are fine, but there are mandatory Saturdays occasionally (twice a month was common). They do provide a week or two of notice for these, which is nice. 

One of my biggest grudges with Tiffany was that, during training, you are in a classroom setting with a trainer who checks every bit of your work, and sometimes even fixes things for you if it would take you too long to do it yourself. However, as soon as you get out of training, you're just kind of dumped onto the work floor to succeed or flounder. You can still ask questions to your superiors, but the advice is much less detailed. Many times, when I asked for a superior to check my product to make sure it was good enough to send to QA, they said it was fine.. and then a day or two later it was rejected from QA and my quality rate went down. 

My other biggest complaint is that, as a setter, you have a speed and a quality rate to follow. However, if your ring is sent to be polished before QA, and the polisher messes up (over-polishes/shaves off some of your piece/ messes up the engraving, etc.), the fault still comes back to you. The polishers do not have a quality rate. So you could be sending out a perfectly fine product that took you a couple of hours to complete, only to find you have to completely re-do it with no rate effect, because of something you can't control. I found this aspect of the job very frustrating.

Final complaint: I was hired on a night shift, which they advertised for even though "night shift" hadn't actually been created yet. I was promised multiple dates for night shift to begin, but it was pushed back month after month. By the time that I left, night shift was still and illusion and the promise of a new date for it to begin still lingered in the abyss, where I assume it will remain.

review_title: Brand Image Being Tarnished by Poor Management Decisions
pros: Tiffany is still a hugely respected brand with international appeal.
cons:
The new variable rate commission structure dealt a huge blow to sales professionals, especially during an economic downturn. The new structure has resulted in large reductions in sales professionals' income and terrible effect on esprit de corps and their ability to provide a high level of customer service.  

Pay graded on performance is not, by itself, the problem. Rather, the new sales goals are often highly unrealistic and do not account for macroeconomic trends beyond sales professionals' control. Failure to meet these goals not only results in decreased pay, but has been used by management as a lever to exert control over sales professionals. 

Many long-term sales pros with sterling records have either quit or been fired. Those remaining have been forced to adapt to a disintegrating workplace environment in which colleagues compete more and more intensely for declining sales, not only among themselves, but with new hires who are unfamiliar with the traditional civility that has mostly characterized the Tiffany sales culture.
