cons: The pay and training could be much better.

review_title: Employees are not valued as  much as customers.
pros: To be a part of a customer's memorable experience is fantastic.  The quality of the merchandise allows me to work with great pride.  There are wonderful resources on the company intranet so that you can learn at your own pace and enhance your own skills and your customer's visits.  Tiffany attracts sales people who have passion and a wish to give great customer service.
cons:
There seems to be little compassion now for sales staff who feel like numbers not people.  Graded harshly on everything by upper management on how you acknowledge a customer to challenges making sales targets.  During challenging economic times there is little empathy and even the most experienced sales people are lacking confidence.
Due to this pressure much work is done outside working hours to build client books so that whilst in work we can stay on the floor and sell.

pros: Working at Tiffany & Co is a great learning experience, and I highly recommend it as a way to polish skills in customer service, sales and teamwork. You get to learn a lot about different gemstones, the benefits are great and the discount doesn't hurt!
cons: Lack of consistency in management team and in company procedures can become a headache not only for the employees but also for the customers. Lack of upward mobility and employee development. Very few people get promoted, so if you are looking for a job where you can grow and develop a career, this will not be the place for you. If the store is not doing well, prepare for a cycle every month in which you start the month very excited and end it stressed out because nobody is making plan. Since your commission depends on how much you sell and achieve over your sales plan, there is a very strong possibility that you will not make as much as you believe you will.

pros: Ok benefits and discount for most things
cons: Micromanagement and poor leadership is at the heart

review_title: Avoid the Vancouver Oakridge location at any cost
pros: Great employee discounts and excellent onboarding training with their training manager. High pay for seasonals. Some SPs and Ops are pretty nice and helpful.
cons:
I would have given a negative star to senior management if I could. Senior management treats full-time and seasonal employees very differently. They are not thankful for anything you do, and gives bad attitude to seasonals only all of the time.  

Senior management team is a complete power troll, who does not understand the word "respect". They try to make you feel uncomfortable and stressed out at all time. Extreme micro-management, does not trust you for anything you do, and is not willing to help/teach you anything. There is absolutely no inclusiveness, management excludes seasonal for everything possible. Senior management gives unreasonable attitude towards seasonals and says NO to seasonal employees only but not the full-times. They are for real low-key bullying seasonal employees, which should never be allowed. Also makes assumption and disrespectful comments about clients coming in/calling the store. They also have extreme low EQ, and does not care about the feelings of seasonal employees. Pretends to be deaf and avoids problem. It is obvious that no one has a say for the senior managment team's behaviour.

PLEASE AVOID THE OAKRIDGE LOCATION AT ANY COSTS. RE-CONSIDER YOUR DECISION BEFORE ACCEPTING YOUR JOB OFFER.

pros: This seemed like an amazing place to work when I first started, but the 'magic' quickly wore off. The name looks great on a resume and helps open doors for future opportunities. You are also expected to maintain a very respectful and professional demeanor while on the sales floor, which is a great skill to have in any work environment. There are many sweet stories you get to hear about when you are in this type of business and it was always exciting selling an engagement ring to someone.
cons: Unfortunately, management was very unprofessional at times (leaving for hours with no explanation, taking extended lunches, doing online shopping during work hours) and seemed completely unsupportive of their sales professionals. They will not support you if there is an issue of who gets credit for a sale, even though you are given extremely steep sales quotas to meet. When I was hired I was promised that I would get two consecutive days off each week, but after awhile I was consistently scheduled for six days in a row with no explanation. The commission structure is a joke and only means something if you meet your monthly goal, which is close to impossible when all of the bestselling items are under $200. It was very hard to remain positive in an environment where the management was not supportive of its staff.

review_title: It's a typical retail job just like any other retail establishment.
job_title: Branch Security Officer in Charlotte, NC
pros: The healthcare benefits are pretty good and a 401k with matching contributions is nice.  It's an easy retail job and the name recognition makes one stand out a bit amongst friends and peers.  If one enjoys the luxury retail atmosphere and the type of clientele luxury retail attracts one might find this a comfortable place to work.
cons: There is no room for growth or professional expansion based on merit.  The company's policy of not promoting from within mean that employees are stuck in their hired positions no matter their skill level or ability.  Sales stay sales, security stays security, and customer service stays customer service.  Management is hired from outside the company and very seldom have comprehensive management skills.  The outstanding and exceptional managers use the company as a springboard to further their career.  This is likely because there is no growth potential with Tiffany.  Any legitimate grievance or complaint regarding the company's policies are met with the threat of termination. The pay is stagnant and 'merit' wage increases can be withheld for arbitrary reasons.  When 'merit' wage increases are given out they range from 1%-3% typically.

job_title: Operations Professional in San Diego, CA
pros: The health benefits are amazing for a retail company.
cons: Avoid the San Diego store at all costs. It would mean a very bitter end to your retail career. If you must work for this company, go to another store. There is no work-life balance unless you are above an assistant store manager. They have little to no regard for your family or loved ones. Very little compensation for hard or consistent work.

review_title: It's just about the money, try not to take it personally or look for personal praise.
job_title: Sales Professional in New York, NY
pros: The status of the company keeps the customers buying our products, even in bad economic times. This creates financial security.  The status is also based on real substance when it comes to customer service, and on the quality of our luxury items, many of which can only be provided by Tiffany. An employee can be proud of that.
cons: Extremely competitive. Don't look to make any friends with colleagues who are in any way in competition with you for sales or promotions, etc.  While they take the way customers are treated extremely seriously, which is good for customers, as an employee, management only cares about how much money you make for them...period.  On the other hand it's not personal, and it's not a meritocracy, if you generate more money,  you are treated a little bit better.

review_title: Tiffany is overall a wonderful and great place to work!
job_title: Customer Service Representative in Jackson Heights, NY
pros:
Lower and upper level management at the main store on 5th avenue will recognize and commend you for successfully meeting and exceeding customer expectations.
Great people, Good company to work for, Pay and benefits are good overall, Good support for employees. 
The prestigious feeling of working for such a well recognized company is undeniable. 
Good opportunities for advancement and upward mobility is rapid if in the right department.
If you are dedicated, ambitious, get along great with people and really good at what you do or go above and beyond your expectations, you will be recognized for the most part and will advance accordingly if the opportunity is there.
cons:
Pay did not increase to keep up with inflation, Can get stuck in a department if you are too good at what you do. 
New hires may start out with higher pay then current employees. 
Advancement opportunities in some departments can be lacking or very slow to materialize.

job_title: Senior Branch Security Officer in Charlotte, NC
pros: Employee discount in store and the online store is always a great deal. Tiffany gives 8 weeks paid time off for new fathers, 12 weeks for mothers. Insurance is ok, no real issues with what is offered. Pay is good.
cons: Local management cares more about selling than about its employees. Customer is always right is an unofficial moto. Customer survey is king. They give you sick days but punish you for using them with a points system. Vacation doesn’t roll over to the next year. High stress for sales professionals to make goals every month. I’ve applied for other positions inside the company and was more or less told no because I didn’t have “experience”. They suggested I leave to get that experience and come back a couple years later. Didn’t want to promote and train from within.

review_title: T&Co. tarnished more than it's sterling silver
pros: The merchandise is a product you can get behind. Employee benefits are generous. Great sales, operations, and store level management employees.
cons: Work life balance is not an option. The company is lacking a voice and a clear path. Current CEO has not proven his leadership to the individuals at the store level and that makes company initiatives difficult to get behind. The message is always changing with no clear explanation or expectation. Upper Management (MVP's and Up) check the box and have no idea what is going on in their markets and stores. They are often incorrect in gauging market trends and don't factor in reality. Too many metrics and not enough getting back to the basics and focusing on the things that work. There's a lot of speaking out of both sides of their mouths.

pros: The discount is worthwhile. Excellent insurance. Fun environment that attracts great people. Opportunity for growth if you can relocate or live in NYC.
cons:
Terrible work/life environment!!! While that is expected with retail hours, what might surprise you is the work never stops! If you are off, expect to receive phone calls and texts from employees, customers and managers and expect to be readily available to help. Expect to be required to check your emails several times a day while one vacation and your day off. 

Sales team is exceptionally compensated which does help retain talent, however the support staff does the heavy lifting and is minimally compensated. Managements’ pay is a joke for anyone less than a Director. Bonuses are annual and based off your overall rating which is subsequently based off the overall store’s performance, not individual performance (as that portion of your review is less than 30%). This means a manager that works extremely hard could receive the same rating, raise and bonus as one that slacks off all year.

review_title: Hard job, not the best commission structure, and no personal life
pros:
Potential commission and bonuses 
Employee discounts
cons:
Commission depends Of the percentage of the goal you sell each month, goals are high and without a client base  most months very difficult to reach, so you only make 1% which is barely anything.
If you leave for training, vacation, sick leave the goal doesn’t get adjusted (it used to and l was hired with term)
Let’s say you have a great month and get paid 3% for your sales a month, and something big you sold it’s being returned for an exchange at the same value next month;
You get a charge back at 3% and if the current month you aren’t doing well (so getting only 1% commission) you won’t get any money until you even out what you owe, even though they spent the same amount with you at the time of the exchange.
Sold something for 50k, got paid $1500, chargeback $1500, new commission $500
The transaction costs you $1000
So you could be paying that back for months and get only paid the base.

You have to be standing for 8 hours

review_title: Good company with very humanity culture
pros: Good company culture, friendly atmosphere
cons: Over come challenges each year brings with a company full of team player

job_title: Sales Professional in Santa Barbara, CA
pros: The employee discount was really nice since all of the jewelry there is overpriced. I thought the commission was good, especially around Christmas time. However, with all retail places that run off of commission, it bounds to get a little catty on the sales floor. The company was really fun to work for. We always had charity events and parties so we got to do good, while getting paid and having fun. Having a great team really made the job more fun. For a high-end jewelry store, Tiffany's is definitely catered more towards the younger crowd so it was more enjoyable to work there than, say, Harry Winston. And it definitely beats working at Zale's!
cons: At the end of the day, it's still just a retail job. Realistically, the highest you will go is management. If you are super optimistic, you might get to work in corporate. Otherwise, there's really no room to grow. I was in college when I worked there and knew I wasn't going to stay forever. It was fun while I was young and I was the envy of my friends. I still miss the job from time to time, especially since now I'm a boring attorney and don't get to play with and handle gorgeous jewelry all the time.

review_title: Was once a great company to work for.....
pros: Working with world class merchandise. Mostly awesome coworkers. Very good benefits and good salary. When I started working for this company in 2002 I knew how lucky I was to have landed the job. By the time I left in 2011, I was burnt out and numb from shock at the horrible changes.
cons: I worked in 3 different branches in 3 different cities, 2 were great the 3rd was horrible! Favoritism is rampant, management incompetence is rampant, the change in the company culture is unbelievable. A company that at one time valued its employees now treats them like dirt. I watched good, hard working people get disposed of like sacks of meat during the "buy outs." It really has become every manager for themselves now! Do yourself a favor and stay away, it's not the Tiffany & Co. it once was!

review_title: No one needs a job this bad
job_title: Full Time in New York, NY
pros:
There are none - literally none. 

Benefits are standard 
Pay is below average for luxury 
Discount is not great considering the merchandise price 
Commission structure is completely unscrupulous and only benefits lifers 
Management is catty and backstabbing 
Dress code is that of a Wall Street banker in the 90’s
cons:
This company is the most vile and unethical place I have ever had the misfortune of working. The favoritism and politics that plague this company far surpasses anything I have ever seen in retail. From top down, rather than doing the right thing they cover up and hide the truth to benefit themselves. 

This brand is supposed to be about relationships. Cultivating a lifetime of special moments And milestones with the customers. They are so far from understanding what that means or looks like. They encourage their employees to shake people down to spend their money buying them off with elaborate galas and event tickets. They pit employees against one another under the guise of “healthy competition.” And do nothing to manage poor behavior if the individual is producing money.

review_title: Great place to sale, but no confidence in Management.
pros: Truly this is easy work, and witj good conscience, if you work hard the pay out is good. Employee discount program is good but you are only paying approx. 50% less then the client and only 20% less on engagement. But it is better then nothing.
cons: Sales in general brings out the worst in people. You do have to worry about someone stealing sales from you. As there are very few people with a good conscience who will not do this, as is my experience. As for management, it is told to you that they are there to help you and while they are good on their promise, it is not lasting and the same issues, you will find, eventually persist. In the end, whoever is making sales or has a deep client book, these are the people managers will place more attention on, as far as requests are concerned, when made. Seems logical, but it does make for a more stressing environment knowing that your requests may not be as lasting, which brings down the confidence in the long term, creating an even more stressing environment.

pros: Perks are great, and luxurious!
cons: Working on holidays and special days

pros: Good benefits compared to other companies - medical, dental.
cons:
Sr management constantly takes time off to go do "leisurly activities" and yet they don't get charged days off - apparently human resources or the big whigs do not see anything wrong with this. The one plus to this is that you don't have to stare at their faces when they are in the office.
Unfair treatment, discrimination, bad HR department, horrible vacation time and personal time and sick days are virtually non-existent. The company policy is ridiculous and does not leave any room for an employee work/family life balance. I'm glad i left because it is not a company to grow with (i was with the company for over 15 years and disappointed i did not leave sooner). Upper management does not seem to care that all employees are miserable and they do not care to do anything about it - all they care about is money and status and reputation. All Tiffany is, is an empty blue box - the fantasy of working here is exactly that.

pros: The only positives about working here are the discounts that employees receive and the decent health benefits
cons: Too much competition between sales associates. The commission structure makes it impossible to make decent money (basically minimum wage). I made more money working as a server for tips when I was working part-time than at Tiffany's full time. The management treats people very unfairly. All they care about is sales quotas that are way too high for the amount of customers that are actually coming into the store. The quotas are pretty much impossible to achieve and the managers do not try to do anything to help. I became pregnant while working here and the managers treated me extremely poorly. They scheduled me to work almost 2 weeks straight without a day off and also scheduled me to work over 11 hours some days. They were not understanding at all when I needed to take breaks to sit down and drink water and even tried to stop me from taking a lunch break just because they thought the sales goals were more important. Not a good work/life balance at all either, so if that is important to you, you should look elsewhere.

review_title: Weird Corporate Culture, Low Pay, Not connected to Stores
pros:
It's a great brand to have on your resume. Some teams are known to work really well together and be collaborative, unlike some other companies in retail/luxury retail where coworkers are known to be much nastier. The dress code in headquarters is now pretty casual, which is nice. 

There's a lot of excitement around the new Design Officer's first year/first collections. Reed Krakoff -- wheee
cons:
Salary is lower than market. Very little opportunity to move upward since the higher up you go, the more people love their jobs. Directors and VPs LOVE it and almost never leave, so there are a lot of lateral moves employees make in order to grow; otherwise, they leave. 

I've worked in 7 other companies and I've never seen the amount of whispering and hushed conversations as I've seen at Tiffany & Co. It's very strange. Information is not shared easily, and everything seems to be a secret.

There has been a lot of movement in upper upper management (CEO left, head designer left), so VERY many things have been shaken up. There have been a lot of organizational changes. Most isn't effecting the retail stores, but corporate has been FEELING it

pros:
Employee discount (50% on silver, 30% other items, promotional days for 50% off everything)
Most of the other associates were amazing, helpful, welcoming, and wonderful to work with
Luxury experience
Experience with hospitality
Jewelry experience
Sales experience
Interacting with established clientele
Pay is great for a part time/seasonal role
cons:
Management is over-bearing and takes things too seriously. I did not receive a single word of praise my entire time working there and was ignored aside from snide remarks and micro-managing. 
Management did not communicate well to each other.
My seasonal position "ended" with hours notice. The other managers were not even told about this. I was assured it was not my performance but because of sales decreases after the holidays.
Commissions cuts are laughable
You are expected to give your sales to the more established associates without question, especially the more pricey sales
You are not even allowed to sell "fine jewelry" as a seasonal professional. If a client asks to see fine jewelry, you will have your sale swooped up from you by a more seasoned associate.

pros: Iconic brand name, looks good on a resume, there's always something to learn, beautiful product (sometimes overpriced, sometimes not), the employee discount is generous. Well paying and good benefits for retail.
cons: The company has realigned it's financial outlook for the worse and some layoffs soon followed. They have completely gone off the deep end about the Chinese consumer when that market is already showing signs of weakness. My store alone has hired Sales Professionals based on the fact they can speak Mandarin and not their retail experience (kind of a slap in the face to seasoned retail professionals). The internal promotion talk is just that, talk. Not enough new product. The increase in online shopping makes it harder to close sales in the store.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Las Vegas, NV
pros:
-The name of the company in itself carries a great deal of admiration and dignity. 
-You get the opportunity to share some of the best times of clients lives with them on a daily basis.  Leaving lasting impressions and creating timeless bonds.
-Although growth opportunities are hard if you do not meet the right Image, you do however get to learn all aspects of the business.  This allows you to use these talents to grow elsewhere.
cons:
-Little room for advancement due to lack of open positions.  It's also rather difficult to meet the ideal "Image" required to advance.  More often then not, its not what or who you know, or even experience, it's "Image."  This leads to good looking leadership, with no clue how to lead or motivate a team.
-The atmosphere is much like being in high school.  Dramatic to say the least.  Couple that with the lack of competent leadership, and you have a volatile working environment.
-The only department the is recognized or appreciated is sales.

pros: A regular salary, not a good salary but regular. You have 10 sick days and 10 vacation days however you get pouts for being sick or late or anything else
cons:
Working in a smaller newer store it difficult. I can't really gage how the company is because the management generally don't know what they are doing. If you can gage it from human resources who are not new it's terrible, they don't return emails and generally don't have the employees backs.
It's such an aggressive atmosphere and in my mind after working for other luxury retailers the customer should never know its a commission position but instead they let their employees run around like animals and not setting a tone. But maybe it's because management is so much older and they find it hard to grasp what to actually do on the sales floor which is why they probably stay in their offices all day and then provide a terrible customer experience when they need to do something simple like a customer repair unless they can pass the buck to someone else. Oh and please don't have s family or any other commitments away form the store, you'll be penalized. And now in the current economy no one wants to take responsibility for lack of sales. If they can pass the buck on that too they will. They also harass half their employees for dress code when they let the other half slip( younger verses older) maybe it's an age thing again....

review_title: Great experience, great company and excellent staff
job_title: Seasonal Operations Assistant in Miami, FL
pros: Beautiful work environment.  Management is very well trained and knows how to bring out the best in their employees.  When you start working for Tiffany, you go into a proven system of business that is easy to learn and follow.  During holiday rush week, food is provided for employees.
cons: Parking is not provided, and in luxury malls the monthly parking fee can be quite high.  As a Seasonal Operations Assistant a big part of your job is to charge customers and finalize the transaction, but you cannot sell or show them merchandise.  When the store gets very busy, customers get very annoyed when they ask for your help and you have to explain that you are there just to process transactions.  Schedules are typical retail schedules, which is to be expected.  You need to invest in high end work clothing since their dress code is very strict.

job_title: Analyst, Merchandising in New York, NY
pros:
- Work life balance (9 to 5 is common in corporate)
- Competitive pay (vs. other luxury companies)
- Good Benefits (Health Insurance, Gym reimbursement)
- Employee Discount (E-Store)
- Nice workspaces and good office location in Manhattan
cons:
- Culture 
(Most employees have worked only at Tiffany their entire career, making the environment very stagnant; Senior and junior people exhibit a high degree of insecurity - they do not want you to learn/know more than they do and are easily threatened by high performers)

- Very limited career development 
(No emphasis on developing skills or crafting a career path, which makes internally grown senior leaders unqualified vs. industry standards; Performance goals are nonexistent or fluff; Senior people appreciate robotic minds and like those who do not question or think out of the box)

- Lack of corporate events/trainings 
(Onboarding is done entirely online; No employee off sites or events that include all levels; No trainings for all levels; No social events within teams like happy hours or team lunches)

review_title: A company that will hire you as a seasonal and keep you there
pros:
*Overtime available during holidays
*People in the department are nice
cons:
*Management uses individuals especially seasonal
*No prospects of transitioning into a permanent position even if you do good work, they just keep you as a seasonal so they do not have to pay benefits
*If you do good work be prepared to pick up other peoples loads 
*The pay is not good
*If you want to eat your lunch during your break, good luck because if you have to warm it up and/or go to the cafe by the time you come back to your desk your break will be over

pros: Good opportunities in management if you are open to relocation.  Promotions are generally from within the company.
cons: Management is not transparent, and leaves you wondering what is motivating their decisions.  Difficult for hourly staff to work their way towards promotion to a supervisory or management position.  Outdated POS, CRM and back office systems.

review_title: After many many years with the company...
pros:
Outside the box - 
Tiffany is a very strong worldwide brand, perhaps the most sought after brand in the world.
The company offers a great product and has many loyal customers. 
The company offered a good severance package to employees in the recent economic downturn.
Overall, there is a good sense of security working for the company, and its nice being part of this wonderful American icon.
cons:
Inside the box - 
Management stinks because much of the management has no core.  The future leaders may destroy the company. The company is turning into a big business and in turn is forgetting about it's roots. 
The management truly believes that anyone can perform any job duty and tries to equalize you. 
If this is the case, why haven't they been able to find a replacement for Louis Comfort Tiffany yet?
Don't try to stand out too much or work harder, you will be leveled by your incompetent manager quickly. 
There are way too many women in management in the company who are trying to prove a point.

job_title: Senior Systems Analyst in Parsippany, NJ
pros: Iconic brand name, the benefits package. Pay is above average if you had spent a number of years working for the company. The products are uniquely designed. Generous discounts for employees.
cons: IT management has changed recently and has ruined the once great culture. Long time employees are not respected and often passed over by people hired from the outside that are less qualified. The IT Department is extremely top heavy, with a number of managers that do not have any direct reports. On the management level they reward incompetence. Just because someone has been with the company for 30 years does not mean they are capable of being a manager. The company is slow to react to technology changes and rely too heavily on IBM and outsourced consultants. They deploy faulty code into production and then management blames everyone but themselves. In certain departments you are required to take off hour on call shifts with no compensation. Career development is nonexistent.

review_title: Suitable as part-time work while in college
pros: Salary is great and quite high compared to most of the other work you can find as a student studying full time. Coworkers are a close knit circle and generally decent people, with only a few exceptions - can be easily handled if you stand up for yourself. Met a few affluent clients who later became business connections and helped me along in my own career. The employee discount is an added advantage.
cons: Too many reviews are conducted where nothing is ever really accomplished. Quite a few in the management team are especially passive aggressive. Frequently missing less than an hour of pay that is hard to notice unless you're paying attention. Then it was a great hassle to chase up because of the aforementioned passive aggressive attitudes. At the end of the day it's still a retail job, and retail jobs are soul-sucking.

job_title: Assistant Store Manager in Atlanta, GA
pros: Good benefits (health insurance, vacation time, merchandise discount), access to merchandise due to stores nationwide, if you work in the NYC area you have better access to training/development due to the close proximity to Corporate.
cons: Employees at the store level have a poor work/life balance. Employees have been promoted into management who process subpar knowledge of how to be an effective leader. The quality of merchandise has steadily declined over the years yet prices have steadily increased. Rampant favoritism in regards to sales professionals with "top clients". When concerns are voiced to management or HR you become a target for retaliation. Minorities do not possess Senior Management positions.

pros: The physical environment is pleasant and the non-management employees are good to work with.  Customers generally are easy to deal with and you work with beautiful products.
cons:
The IT systems are shockingly out of date.  Any transactional function is done in DOS-based systems that are painful to work with.  Very little useful information is available on the internal site.  You get better results by calling someone at another store than by searching the internal site.

Enlightened management is nowhere to be found in my store.  The assistant manager is duplicitous and the store director provides no leadership.  Meanwhile the sales manager is trying to find her way out of a paper bag.

pros: Ridiculously good discount for overpriced items. Nice perks like being able to stub your toe and be late for work for 6 months. No accountability whatsoever. Only better place to work was the Post Office before the economic downturn. Subsidized oxtail stew and other disgusting items that the entire staff, due to diversity, is forced to eat, are a daily "treat". Pretty place to work. Most people are pleasant.
cons: Disrespect is rampant and misinterpreted according to where one hails from. Fear of Human Resources is the norm. Laziness, rudeness and "I got mine" is rewarded. Racial profiling and hostility is the norm. They can't even get a simple concept like wardrobing right. Major disconnect between Executive and front line.

pros: Overall a positive, friendly and polite culture with great pride in the brand felt and expressed among most employees throughout the organization. There is a lot of integrity here with Tiffany people wanting to be good stewards of a singular American luxury brand with democratic values demonstrated by aspiring to socially responsible business practices and serving customers who have a broader range of disposable income. The new leadership campaign to  reduce the calcified silos and improve overall coordination should help improve the prospect of performance-based advancement and overall business results.
cons: Traditional, careful and hierarchical culture with paternalistic tendencies resulting in senior management making most decisions. Middle management usually must go along with whatever they are told or risk not being promoted or worse. Generally, the compensation packages are below average and benefits package is trending toward sub-par.

review_title: Great company, too much red tape
pros:
Beautiful products
Quality control
Environmental awareness
Vacation policy
Hours for retail reasonable
Proud heritage
Global presence
Interesting clientele
talented artists
cons: Sales projections have been a bit erratic during the economic downturn, placing a lot of pressure on retail sales and management to perform in tough times.  Holiday hours are long.  Career advancement is difficult.  Higher level management jobs rarely open up.  Too much emphasis is placed on the performance appraisal given by your immediate manager.  If there is a personality conflict or favoritism, there are no checks and balances to ensure that the feedback is accurate and not rooted in personal dislike or favoritism of the employee.

review_title: Company has lost sight of importance of valuing, rewarding and offering internal career progression to its employees.
pros: Nice employee store with discounted merchandise. Company is well regarded in high end luxury market. Corporate offices are nice and in good location in Manhattan.
cons: Too many ongoing changes since lay offs of 2008, has left a very nervous employee population creating a very sour and demotivating working environment. Management not focused on right priorities and needs to communicate more openly and honestly on all levels. Pay not in line and very poor yearly increases are given, even for best performers. Very political environment creates an unpleasant daily experience. HR is very ineffective, and basically will do nothing to back up employees. Be careful about continuing to hire top management from the same foreign country.

pros: Some friendly coworkers in sales, operations and security. Employee discount was decent but felt like a cash grab after learning the (low) cost of making some pieces.
cons:
TERRIBLE management - uneducated managers who were blatantly biased and hilariously over-the-top with theatrics. The store director cracks her whip at the slightest thing; the manager is a placeholder who has zero use and no pull with Chinese customers; the two assistant managers are new and too green. Constant excuse of "I'm busy" and "we can discuss this later", when the issue would be swept under the carpet. Consistently high turnover rate - four staff members (30% of the team) has left within the last few months. Told to speak up and pushed for a two-way dialogue to improve on situation in the store, then disciplined for voicing my concerns, standing my ground and not suppressing the unfair treatment. 

Clients would always come into the store and complain about cheaply made merchandise - Tiffany doesn't have a warranty on any of their products.

review_title: Unskilled management team with skillful employees
pros: Good people (not management). Good pay.
cons:
For a company that is in the Luxury industry - This sure is a very unpolished diamond with a ton of dirt "at the top" of a real diamond. The people who make the company are good hard working people with every intention of doing good for the company. However, as uneducated and under qualified as the management team is to lead these people it is bound to continue its poor performance. Some of this might be specific to the RI facility. People's interests take a back seat in every conversation. They strongly encourage a culture of "do as you are told". Very demotivated workforce producing sub-optimal results due to lack of any direction and multiple meaningless changes that affect the employees negatively and has no positive impact on the business in the long run. The management team does not know how to identify talent and wastes every resource at their disposal. Employees are shown a closed HR door when they have issues. 

Minimal leadership training. No real employee development opportunities. There is no room for diverse perspectives. The results are just as bad as you’d expect.

review_title: managers will lie to your face to protect themselves
job_title: Sales Professional in Las Vegas, NV
pros: employee discount, young coworkers make for a high energy environment
cons:
-new commission scale, with economic downturn they suddenly made commission scale goal based which means the average sales associate gets a pay cut, unrealistic goals set by management
-deteriorating brand (so much silver merchandise and not necessarily good quality, now new metal with copper retailing much higher than silver, are you a luxury brand or not) which leads to a mix of customers, international customers not too familiar with the brand or think of it as fashion brand
-no room for growth (rarely promotes from within, would rather hire new management with no experience in retail)
-pay is low when compared to other luxury companies
-management will do anything including lying to your face about things previously said to protect themselves and their jobs
-management will not stand up for you, no support, but you will get talked to over every single minor transgression 
-management is stupid, lack of product knowledge, policies, don't know how to use the register 
-management plays favorites, talks crap about other employes and members of management team behind each others back
-really the management attributed to the one of the most unprofessional settings I've ever encountered

review_title: Good company as a whole, but the retail side has its expected drawbacks
job_title: Sales Professional in San Francisco, CA
pros: Excellent benefits. Great perks like a gym reimbursement and cell phone discount. I get the feeling that working on the corporate level would be more satisfying on than on the retail level. But even as far as retail is concerned, they're generous with holidays and even offer "floating holidays" (a holiday day off to take at a later date) if you have to work on a typical day off like Memorial Day. Also, they're very open to transferring if you'd like to relocate and there's a great path/opportunities for career advancement if you're looking to move into corporate.
cons: Tiffany & Co. prides itself on customer service to a fault. In luxury goods you're certainly going to encounter a share of entitled patrons. They can insult you to your face and you still have to put on a smile. Sales is sales so be prepared to encounter sneaky coworkers who will try to steal your sales. As a plus though - the company offers avenues to escalate an investigation if there is a case of major commission stealing.

review_title: Best Job Ever to Worst Job Ever
pros: Initially, there were great opportunities for growth and development, a cohesive team environment, and interesting projects. Operations ran smoothly and the workload was very reasonable and well prioritized.
cons: Over the course of my employment, due directly to a change in leadership, it became a totally abusive and toxic environment in which my team saw over 50% attrition. Since this was apparently not strategically intentional, it demonstrates how poor the management has become. Additionally, there was outward sexism that hadn't been prevalent when I started. The projects became dull and the development opportunities disappeared. The operations went from smooth to chaotic and terribly run.

review_title: Terrible Managers and Supervisors that make up policies and strengthening workplace bullying
pros:
- Good discounts on jewelry and in proximity to other corporate headquarters in Parsippany
- People's eyes light up when you say you work for Tiffany's
- Retail store sales people are very nice (unfortunately I don't work with them)
cons:
- Managers and supervisors lack competency in providing a positive, open work environment
- Cultural bullying
- lack of work-life schedule balance for 'lower level' employees, while managerial levels are never "available" for support.
- Micro-managing 
- Many dissatisfied employees

pros: Great commission opportunities and benefits. Good staff discount. You have two personal days a year. Product is pretty good too.
cons: Management are so patronising, inexperienced and lack empathy. If you take longer than 5 minutes in the toilet, you will be made to awkwardly explain why in front of other staff members like a school child. Targets are not adjusted if you are away on holiday. There is a lot of conflict of interest, with managers hiring their friends as supervisors, who are rude, bully staff and are on a power trip. They get away with everything as they are friends with management. They also get big sales passed down to them as opposed to being fairly distributed to other members of staff. oh and good luck trying to get your holidays in. They’ll reject them and when you ask to see when you can actually take them, you will be told it’s on the managers list but not top of the list. So you probably won’t get them.

review_title: Okay experience. Not a viable career.
pros:
-Nice employee discount

-Good onboarding program

-Fun stories from customers

-Beautiful products

-Nice coworkers

-Food was abundant

-Really supportive management! (If you’re lucky.)
cons:
-I never experienced many bad customers. But it was pretty astounding how some of them could act so cheap, yet self-entitled. 

-Disorganized HR

-Many employees were overqualified and underpaid

-According to many employees, management was always a common issue at the retail locations

-It’s very common for the company to hire externally for management positions. Some of the management couldn’t do basic arithmetic or spelling. It made no sense how they were even hired.

-Too much pressure to sell, sell, sell. You constantly felt like you were just a number. Some of the management didn’t know what else to talk about.

-Too much useless busywork. If you just finished cleaning some products on your own, and management didn’t watch you do it, you can bet that they’d ask you to re-clean those same items once more.

-High turnover rate. The only people who had been with the company for 10+ years were nearing retirement age.

pros: Great benefits and pay, become really close and friends with the Sales Professionals.
cons:
Micro-Management Environment, never consistent and always pulling you in different directions as well as no one is ever on the same page when it comes to the Managers. Must have patience as management has a tendency of walking all over you and talking down to you even when you have a wealth of sales experience and are making sales. 

No matter what you do or have well you do it they will continue to pick and pick and pick. Oh and not to mention that talking to another Sales Professional when it is completely dead for hours is absolutely frowned upon and will get yelled at for it. 

Very common for people to get let go with no warnings or write-ups or explanations. Always feel like you could be next and never disagree with any of the managing partners.  It is sad to see such a beautiful company with such great heritage to treat their employees with so much disresecpt.

review_title: Good work/life balance, little opportunity for advancement, unfair promotions
job_title: Senior Analyst in New York, NY
pros:
Having worked at a few companies, T&Co has the best work/life balance and a pleasant work environment. Employees are very respectful towards one another and are always willing to help. Rarely have to stay late, a true 9:30-5:30 work schedule. Lenient vacation policy.

Good place to work if you're a manager or above. You get a bonus, extra week of vacation and the option to work from home. But good luck getting promoted. Manager and Director positions rarely open up and when they do, people are normally "pre-selected" based on how well liked you are not experience and performance.
cons: The pay at T&Co. is below the market average, very small annual pay raises, unfair and inconsistent promotions, little opportunity for growth unless you're one of the "selected" ones or related to upper management, poor retention of talent.

review_title: Good co-workers, great product, working environment became highly pressurized since mass layoffs around 2008
pros: Great product and company history, many opportunities to learn via educational programs.
cons: Since the economy fell in 2008, morale became extremely poor as mass layoffs from entry level to the top occurred. Leadership from management up espouse high levels of political correctness, and workers became afraid to express themselves as the individuals they are. Leadership has failed in recent years to hold to the vision of the founder of the company, moving away from the prime focus of creating the greatest works of jewelry in the world to profit--at the expense of the company's stellar reputation.

review_title: An extremely hierarchical culture resistant to change makes this a demoralizing workplace for junior thru  .
pros:
The company and brand are recognized on a global level, and senior-level employees appear to enjoy generous compensation and work conditions. 
NYC headquarters are beautiful and well-located.
cons:
The organizational structure is extremely vertical, with most tasks requiring levels and levels of corporate approval. 
There are many misclassified workers/permalancers who have worked there for years and are expected to perform as staff, although they are denied benefits and recently even overtime pay. 
Race appears to inform personnel decisions in the predominantly Asian interactive media department, with most employees of other races holding freelance and not staff positions. 
Innovation is discouraged even in the creative department. Management prefers to repeat previous efforts than to experiment or break new ground.
Seniority and favoritism heavily influence both decisions and staff interactions.

pros: Great discount, history and credibility, decent training, great sales conference, decent pay, good benefits. Some nice colleagues.
cons: Management at a store level is not respectful to their employees. Most of the sales associates are more qualified then the managers at this location. Do not give you a chance to build your client book, threaten termination daily. With an extensive history in sales, if they were nicer I would have invited my friends, family, and past clients to view and/or purchase. After seeing no respect was in place here, I moved on.

pros: Nothing good about it except the discounts.
cons: Management is the worst, they just side with the regular full-time people for everything. They need to hire more experienced, older people who know what they're doing. Constantly bullied and looked down upon. Training was useless since they teach you about diamonds rather than the metals you are actually selling so you sound like you don't know what you're talking about on the sales floor. Everyone is very unhelpful, long hours, they don't compromise. I was hired in September, didn't get contacted to start working til November, if I had known, I would've definitely looked for a different job.

review_title: Everything that glitters isn't gold or diamonds
job_title: Anonymous Employee in New York, NY
pros: Great stepping stone, discounts, friendly staff. I worked with a great team so I loved going to work everyday. But if you get the wrong manager and you try to move around they can totally ruin your chances of any movement within the company.
cons: Profit driven, employees are a second thought. There are so many grate people working for Tiffany but so much goes unnoticed. I was turned off on how much they say they offer ie., tuition reimbursement but they make it near impossible to get it with all of the requirements.

review_title: Well known brand and that gets you in the door at many other companies
pros: Tiffany is a solid company and after 178 its safe to assume they aren't going any where.  There are a lot of people there who have been there for 10+ years.
cons: The benefits are better than pay, but they factor in benefits to your overall compensation package. The pay is getter because they realize you get what you pay for. A lot of younger people are not willing to come to a company for the name alone. They want to be compensated financially. They need more diversity on an executive level.

pros: Tiffany has a brand name and has good pay and benefits.
cons: Sales people try to avoid customers. Most of the Managers are hardly seen on the sales floors. Chinese sales reps only greet  the chinese unless there are presence of managers. Most of the lady managers have the high bureaucratic attitude and their behavior with the other employees like masters. Most of the lady managers are so snobish that, they are hardly seen to be smiling what is the pre-condition of a good customer service. Male managers are comparatively good human. Their are also no set rules for recruitment process, recruitment is done whimsically and at the will of the above lady managers so you can imagine what will be the outcome.

review_title: Flexibility to do the work you do best, as long as you can navigate around all the red tape
job_title: Human Resources Manager in Jacksonville, FL
pros: In many corporate jobs, there is the ability to evolve your job around your strengths.  Relationship-driven culture, family-like feeling, recognition for work well-done.  Team-driven work environment, brainstorming and collaboration is valued.  Willingness to promote from within.  Great education benefits.
cons: Lots of old-timers are in roles they are underqualified for, and have a surprising amount of power to squash innovation.  Have to be patient and creative in working around red tape and politics to get anything done.  Low salaries and minimal to non-existent yearly merit increases.  Only way to get salary up to market value is to secure an external offer and threaten to leave.

pros: Relatively low stress. Predominantly female environment. Less competition than other companies. Stable company and very socially responsible. Good image. A very comfortable place to work if you don't have very high ambitions or a very agressive attitude.
cons: A somewhat passive aggressive political work culture. Everyone seems nice and pleasant and pretends to like eachother but there is a whole lot of backstabbing. To be successful, it is not important to be smart, successful, or a good employee, just have a few babies and get promoted. The middle management structure is so incompetant that it would be better if it didn't exist. Upper management seems very confident and able, but they are blind to the middle management's many failures.

pros: Good working enviroment among hourly workers, stressful if you have a quota to meet but high risk, high rewards. Has some opportunity for growth if you are willing to travel. Non sales staff positions only good for entry level, but it looks good on a resume for other luxury jobs.
cons: Management is bad, too much favoritism. Management makes examples of hourly staff, NEVER setting the example themselves. Regionals need to pay attention to the employee surveys. HR staff is untrustworthy, if you ask them to look into complaints, they will instead go tell that manager what "you" said and you will receive retaliation.

review_title: Low pay and disorganized structure with eye to the past
job_title: Merchandising Manager in New York, NY
pros: Benefits are ok, health insurance is average, basic gym reimbursement of under 400 a year. Nothing amazing. 10 sick days and after you take about 5, you're under serious monitoring. There are some very nice colleagues, but many of the great people have been leaving over the last 2 years.
cons: Pay is low and non competitive, hours become very long at the office. Total Chaos and disorganization - your job can be changed by company/management on a whim without prior notice! - many people don't know this about Tiffany. Promises are not honored by management. Incompetent individuals get away with not doing work while competent individuals receive exuberant amount of work and are penalized for small mistakes.

job_title: 12hr Machine Operator in New York, NY
pros: easy work, and it was close to home. plus the work hour fitted my schedule
cons: the pay, the way time is kept for overnight workers.  Was told i would get a 48hr week and a 36 hour workweek per pay period, but thats not the case.  was told i was going to receive 20hrs ot pay per paycheck but only getting less than 12hrs.  sacrifice weekends for nothing the employees get no benefits for working weekends.  was told we had to work holidays but we get "double pay" all that is is u get paid for working, and then the holiday pay.  normal company pay for holiday anyways.   upper management and the hr department are completely lost.  they do not know what is going on or how things work.  night shift guys get fully shafted.  company constantly doing layoffs then hiring new people mostly people who speak english as a second language so they can take full advantage of their ignorance.

job_title: Sales Professional in Las Vegas, NV
pros: Very nice and luxurious atmosphere. Very good learning experience in high end retail atmosphere. Sales people do not do any housekeeping. The product is relatively easy to sell because the customer knows the Tiffany name therefore knows the upstanding quality of the product. Tiffany products almost sell themselves without much explanation. The benefits are really good and the pay is mostly decent.
cons: There is tons of favoritism by management. You're either a favorite or not. The favorites get promoted to selling the higher priced items and get lower goals therefore can make a lot more money than those that don't brown nose and are not favored by management. There is very little chance to move up in the company.

pros: Tiffany & Company has a reputation for beautiful jewelry, quality products, excellent craftsmanship, timeless style, and good customer service. If you are a hard worker and you care about your job, your responsibilities, and you care about helping client's - you will find fulfillment in your position.
cons: If you work at the retail level - and you are not mobile, there are only management positions available and even those positions are few and far between. There is definitely favoritism for certain employees who get exactly what they want but if that does not bother you or affect you in any way, then it is fine.  No job is going to be perfect.

pros:
The company discounts were pretty good - although even at a discounted rate - you're still buying from Tiffany's - which can be very expensive..  
If you work in an area where it's not micro-managed and genuine, and there are areas like that, you may like working here.  There is tuition reimbursement IF it gets approved from management.  If the education you are going for is unrelated to your current role or if the school is not "accredited" - you may not qualify.
cons: Well, it's retail - so from September - December you have no life other than work - especially if you're in a sales role or in related departments. But the worst part about working for Tiffany's was the undermining, corporate bullying, mental cruelty - and cover-up that goes on there.  And the fact that this continues to go on and on would be down right appalling for any company - but it's even more surprising coming from this iconic institution.

job_title: Sales Professional in Los Angeles, CA
pros: Company is perfect for learning about Jewelry, and getting started in the luxury world.  Once you have worked for the company, you really can go to any other luxury brand.  Things really do change based on the location you work in, and the quality of the Director in place.
cons: Company has changed drastically over the last few years.  New, added pressure is forced on the sales staff, and they have pushed out most of the tenured employees.  Most people come and stay for around a year, but eventually move on, as they find a better environment elsewhere.  Jobs on the sales floor with Tiffany have become entry-level, more geared towards people just coming out of college.

review_title: Decent Company; Orlando branch breeds horrible management
pros: Company benefits and hourly pay contributed to my longevity of suffering through a 40 hour work week with Orlando's management.
cons:
The Orlando branches management is a quintessential kakistocracy and managers will shirk when confronted with their lack of comportment and/or proficiency.  You will receive many hortatory speeches, but will soon grasp that store leadership is nothing more than desultory waste.
If you join this company with the ideals of a Security/Loss Prevention Professional the shock of your daily duties will take a period of time to wear off.  Accept employment here with caution if you are incapable of blindly conforming to mediocrity and incompetence from leadership.

pros: Impressive name to be associated with. Relatively good benefits. Decent employee discount. Solid paid job training. Acquired foundational skills transfer to many other positions, companies, or even interpersonal relationships. Continued efforts to green company implemented at many levels, both visible and invisible to public.
cons: Traditional company values add to the company's enduring legacy while others stagnate. The conservative company culture is repressive with many outdated or misguided rules. HR appears frequently unwilling or unable to assist employees. Inadequate career development or guidance from superiors or HR. Management seem to strive to impress each other instead of fostering employee achievement. Individual efforts and contributions are infrequently recognized appropriately. Management micromanages and motivates with fear rather than rewarding good performance. Education, experience, tenure, talent, merit, and ambition seem to play no role in advancement while the same few get promotion after award.

review_title: Like watching the big, beautiful Titanic sink...
job_title: Sales Associate in San Francisco, CA
pros: I love Tiffany, always have and always will.   I loved my job, most of my coworkers, most of the products, and most of the clients.  The discount is great, most people will take part time/seasonal work for the discount alone.  The pay is decent after 1 year, but it takes some time to build up.  The pressure to buy everything Tiffany sucks away your income.  The stories are great.  The few corporate trainings (once a year) and client entertainment opportunities (maybe once a year) are fun, but far and few between.
cons: Manipulation, racism, and laziness.  Oh and the in store traffic is down about 50% across the country.  The worst part about my experience was the blatant racism, sexism, favoritism, and political upheaval in almost every team.  Every sales staff has their issues, but Tiffany is consistent with all of their teams in these categories.  A lot of the times you'll hear reviews on here where people say "they don't care about you they just care about the numbers".   The management will pretend to care, sit down and hold your hand and tell you everythings going to be ok, to get you back out there selling as hard as you can, then a week later they break the news sheepishly that whatever the problem is, is still a problem and nothing could be done about it and oh well time to move on.  This is a consistent form of strategy with management and communication for sales disputes, customer service issues, payroll issues, vacation time, sick time, etc.  The 'lets talk about it, go away, ok sorry cant do anything bye' strategy is implemented on a daily basis to get you to shut up.  There is 'growth' opportunities in that most of middle management has been with the company for 5-10-20 years, which is great because they have knowledge on the product, but they move incredibly slow compared to the new management talent a lot of competing brands acquire.  Management is very stuck in their ways, follow the manual from the 90's, any HR issue is relayed about 15 times until the staff gives up.  There's a lot of miscommunication and over-communication and no result.  Sales are wayyyyyyyyyyyy down from years ago, they're waddling through a worse slump than the recession in 08.  The company rolls out 100's of new products, jumbles the prices, doesn't take away old products.  Customers are overwhelmed and disinterested, the brand is fading.  The company survives on the Asian business, so if you're CHinese in America, the company will hire  you and treat you like royalty.  Everyone else is just commonfolk hired to assist the Chinese in their takeover.  Trump is a fan of Tiffany for a reason. ....

review_title: I regret taking a role in this company
pros: Decent salary and that’s pretty much it
cons:
So many complaints about this company. They want you to do your work (and the work of 3 other people) but do not provide proper training material or update information. In reference to work/life balance I was told during my interview that they prided themselves on flexibility and balancing life and work. Well that was lies. My time in scrutinized and micromanaged and as a salaried employee. Time off is nothing special. You get three weeks and the bare minimum of holidays. And god forbid you try to use sick time. The company offers 10 sick days which you use or lose but they encourage you NOT to use it and tell your your performance score can be affected by using sick time. 

All in all it was a bad decision coming to this company. I should have stuck it out in my prior role Until a better opportunity came about.

job_title: Sales Associate in New York, NY
pros: Before the 2008 layoffs, the company had the illusion of having a heart. Don't trust anyone there today.
cons: I have heard that the current commission system is a joke and only benefits the company by pitting everyone against one another.

review_title: Once a good place to work, but not so good now
pros: The clients that you meet are the best thing about working here!   employee discounts,
cons: Lack of qualified store managers and Vice Presidents.  Male employees are treated unfairly.  The company won't stock enough merchandise at the stores.  Store Managers play favorites when assigning sales goals, doing performance evaluations, and scheduling hours.  Too much busy paperwork assigned to sales professional.

pros: Decent work hours for retail and good benefits
cons:
I worked at Tiffany's for a few years with hopes of promotional opportunities with hard work and dedication.  I soon realized that was a dead end.  Promotion from the outside was common and preferred because they could continue with their unscrupulous behavior Management was riddled with individuals hardly qualified for the job and from my experience constantly undermined the mission statement of the company.  I wouldn't invest in the company from my experience and my knowledge of the quality of upper management.  Smaller locations such as Austin, TX, would hold merchandise and ultimately hurt the bottom line of the entire company.  

Almost non-existent raises. 

A co-worker was denied an interview because he was active in the military.  I will no longer shop at Tiffany's because of this.  

I realize this review sounds like a scorned ex- employee, but its not.  I understand that management has to make unpopular decisions sometimes, but their behavior and actions went to far and I realized it was my time to leave.

review_title: All Depends on Which Store You Work
pros: Compensation is very generous, given the nature of the work.  Benefits are excellent.  You have the chance to really develop a relationship with your clients and have them enrich you.  Cache and name help with closing sale.
cons: If you've got a good management team that knows what they're doing, you're all set.  If not, and you've got management that just wants suckups, then it's not fun.  Just focus on doing your job and doing it well in that case and don't be one of the brown nosers.

pros:
* Nice employee discounts.
*  Nice to have a store on site.
cons:
* People on lower management and leadership positions are very incompetent in the IT Dept.  A lot of these people have no real technical degrees other than maybe one year certificate from Chubbs Institute and have no idea what they are doing.  
*  HR has an impressive employee portal that is suppose to help new employees adapt and get integrated into the culture.  Except that leaders don't follow thru and you are basicly on your own, there is no enthusiam and since the leaders lack leadership skills they don't make time for you.  
*  In IT people are expected to work on their lunch hour and newbies have to stay until after hours to get time from their leaders this doesn't happen every once in a while.  It happens consistently.
*  Because of the leaders incompetency, they spend a lot of time in redundancy work and this gives the apperance of them working hard, but they are just working very inefficiently.

pros: The clients! They are truly what make a business! If it wasn't for the great people I come in contact with everyday, I might look to go elsewhere.
cons: Very 2 faced management. I never worried about Integrity of the company when I started years ago, but this location brought a director on from Louis Vuitton who lacks emotional intelligence. She wants the store to run itself, while she sits in her office and figures out who her next Target is. With my experience in the last 2 years I've come to realize that it's a very politically run environment. If you are liked, you may be ok, if not you can expect to be weeded out. I've been in retail for 10 years since graduating college and this is one of, if not the absolute worst experience I've ever had. Sad, because you wouldn't expect that from such a luxury company.

job_title: Senior Analyst in New York, NY
pros: I met some amazing individuals while working here.  I have to say my peers were the best part.  People were respectful and encouraging.  The company is well respected and environmentally sound.
cons: Promotions are hard to come by and so is training unless you're a manager.  The office environment can be quite toxic depending on who you work for.  The work life balance is informally established by your boss so it can vary.  People who address issues with HR or upper management are hurt in the long run.  It's better to just stay quiet or leave.

pros: The company offered great pay and many shifts. Birthdays were milestones that were celebrated with cake. Working there was fairly easy with great rewards such as fun team members.
cons: Changing management team made it difficult to develop a strong and trusting relationship with managers. There was no room or opportunity for further development and growth within the company. There wasn't flexibility in availability where managers would force you to work even though you've provided reason for unavailability months in advance. Some managers were unprofessional where they brought personal life into the workplace and let out their stress onto employees.

pros:
Tiffany is a  good company to work for but it is very challenging. They have a good staff discount program and good commission. They do lots of training throughout the year, with accomodation, food and travel expenses paid for.
Private medical care offered.
cons:
They have extremely high expectations and you are expected to meet high targets and clientele to a high standard. The commission and pay is good but its a job not for the faint hearted as you either work hard or sink. You are expected to do a lot throughout your shifts, as well as giving 100% to every client. This may be dependant on manager but their annual review is graded very harshy, so it is very hard to progress unless you live in London, where there are lots more opportunities. 
Long hours and almost always weekends.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in New York, NY
pros: After leaving Tiffany's and working where I do now, I realize how cushy of a job I had. The hours were always 9 - 5 and if I needed to stay late for a project it was usually until 5:30. The benefits were fantastic and the culture was kind.
cons: I wanted more and to work harder, I wanted more responsibility and unfortunately they would not support me in those needs. It wasn't until I was leaving did they offer me the position I had been pushing for, for over a year. The pay was not great.

review_title: No growth opportunity (both salary and career)
job_title: Associate Manager in New York, NY
pros: The only good thing is the employee discount
cons:
- company does not appreciate employees, no work life balance
- People left the company (either fired or found a better opportunity) and the company does not fill those vacancies. The ones left have to pick up all the work with no salary increase or compensation.
- No bonus 
- No career advancement opportunity at all. Because you are given too much work to do. Of course, you are unable to excel since it's way more than the workload you can handle. At year end review, the company use this against you and give you a bad rating. Thus, you do not get any salary increase nor bonus.
- Overall, it's a terrible place to work at. 
Please expect nothing when you work there.
- Culture is really bad as well.

review_title: No longer a happy, healthy, energized place to work
job_title: Anonymous Employee in New York, NY
pros: Great brand recognition, nice physical environment to work, fair compensation.  Many of the people at all levels, especially those who have been there a long time, care deeply about company tradition, the brand, employees and customers.  Lofty environmental sensitivities.
cons: New leadership appears to care nothing about Tiffany's internal culture or employee satisfaction.  No work/life balance at all.  There's no clear consistent corporate vision or strategy.  Product strategy and merchandise assortment is an internal joke at the store level.  IT systems are embarrassingly outdated and CRM applications are so poorly designed that they are impossible to use productively.  There are huge inconsistencies in expectations and the resources provided to achieve them.  Sad to say, but once the glitter fades, Tiffany is no longer different than any other mall retailer.

review_title: It's great if you work in a Top 25 store, if you don't?  Meh.
pros: Great reputation, good (not great) earning potential, good benefits, on-going training, GIA tuition reimbursement. Addition of Francesca Amfitheatrof as first ever female director of design  was much needed design "shot in the arm" for a company who's jewelry offerings had gotten stale. Leader in environmental protection practices.
cons:
Poor work/life balance. Political culture. No local advertising outside of NYC, SF, LA, Chicago which inhibits growth and earning potential in other markets.  Top 25 stores performance dictates every corporate decision to the detriment of smaller stores with amazing growth potential  i.e. merchandise transferred out the same day it arrived for client showings, no marketing/events budgets, et al.  On-line business set in direct competition with brick and mortar. Compensation realignment that favors high-volume stores/markets. Base pay not commensurate with local cost of living indexes.  
In the five years I worked for TCO, compensation structure changed, we lost holidays with our families, and hours of operation were extended, even though our anchor (Neiman Marcus) was closed. The company doesn't invest in local advertising so even after being open for eight years, people would still remark daily that they "never knew" there was a store in town.  I exceeded my sales plan every year by double digits, I am a producer, and my potential was stunted because I didn't work for one of the "top 25".  That is precisely why I left the company.  Excellent people are only valued if they work in one of those locations.

review_title: Impressive At First, But Tarnished - In Need of Polish
pros:
- Regardless of whether or not they like their job, many employees respect the brand and are proud/feel lucky to work here.
- Very ethical company with clear values that performs a lot of good around the world.
- Great and progressive benefits but very hard to get them.
- Incredible discount. Likely no other company has such a generous discount and extremely low priced items for employees. Many employees stay only for the discount or specifically return for it.
- Promotions seemingly become easy to get once you get an 'in' to the manager/director seats. 
- Very friendly, approachable, and cooperative senior staff. Even the chief executives are accessible and approachable.
- Very many perks and relationships with other companies, meaning lots of corporate discounts.
- Very aesthetically driven and cohesive branding strategy.
- If working on the retail side, customers can be very pleasant and the retail experiences or 'nightmares' aren't much of a worry. People feel lucky just to shop there and behave unless they're problem customers.
- The name and status leads to many interesting and artistic experiences - creative types thrive.
- Strong woman and LGBT presence. 
- Decent mix of younger and older employees.
- Extremely friendly corporate staff and many employees with impressive history.
- There is always some sort of training or event, and the majority of events are catered.
- Beautiful shops, locations, and corporate offices.
- No hesitation to offer overtime and they aren't strict about working hours.
cons:
- Very political in every sense of the word. Hiring seems to be decided on connections and most successful employees are affluent.
- No such thing as getting a foot in the door - the company is very resistant to give people a chance to develop skills and expects everyone to be fully trained from the start.
- People can get fired at any time, and managers are more focused on saving themselves than developing their teams.
- Depends too heavily on "seasonal" and contract employees. Seasonal and temporary workers can be there for years and work with no benefits, paid time off, and no feeling of job security. Headcount is the most important thing and real talent management is honestly non-existent.
- VERY high pay disparity between employee levels. Managers and higher level employees pull in exorbitant amounts of money while lower level employees can barely scrape by. Some high level or long tenure salespeople, however, do get paid very well.  
- Aggressive and stressful sales strategy focused on quantity over quality.
-There always seems to be a revolving-door position or department somewhere and steps aren't taken to address it.
- Managers and directors are very fair-weather. Everyone is very nice but rarely deliver frank news and everyone seems to be afraid to deliver honest answers. There is always a push to focus on the good and ignore the bad. The illusion of grandeur wears off very quickly.
- Non-stop meetings that often don't get anything done.
- Extremely top-heavy and political company. Everyone seems to be either a manager, director or a vice president. Sometimes there are managers without a direct team to manage with nebulous job titles. Sometimes managers are a department of one or two.
- Employees are rarely developed upon and promoted unless they are in high leadership roles. Making lateral or cross-departmental moves can be impossible or take years to achieve.
- The name and luxury attracts unsavory, demanding, and toxic personalities that end up being catty and political employees. This is especially bad in the retail locations.

review_title: I liken it to being in a cemetery or museum. Quiet, the occasional lookie loo,  and not busy.
